channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2015 The New York Times Company

item.title: Venezuelan Opposition Claims a Rare Victory: A Legislative Majority
item.description: For the first time in years, government opponents have won most of the seats in the National Assembly, handing a setback to President Nicolás Maduro.
item.dc:creator: WILLIAM NEUMAN
item.media:description: Voters in Caracas, Venezuela, on Sunday. The opposition rode economic discontent to victories in congressional races.

item.title: A Chinese Folk Artist’s Descendants Are Split by the Government’s Use of Their Family Legacy
item.description: Figurines used to promote the “China Dream” of President Xi Jinping have become a point of contention as some relatives of the original sculptor, recalling mistreatment by the Communist Party, seek to keep politics out of their business.
item.dc:creator: IAN JOHNSON
item.media:credit: Sim Chi Yin for The New York Times
item.media:description: Clay figurines, made in a style recognized across China as historical folk art, are being used in a Communist propaganda campaign, “China Dream.” Relatives of the sculptor who founded the style and studio 200 years ago have objected to its appropriation.

item.title: University Time: Tashfeen Malik Was a ‘Saudi Girl’ Who Stood Out at a Pakistani University
item.description: Teachers remember Ms. Malik, who was born in Pakistan but spent most of her life in Saudi Arabia, as a polite and driven student. But the timing and circumstances of her shift into militancy remain a mystery.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: DECLAN WALSH
item.media:description: The main gate of Bahauddin Zakariya University, where Tashfeen Malik studied pharmacy, in Multan, Pakistan, on Sunday.

item.title: At Paris Climate Talks, Top French Envoy Tries to Avoid Mistakes of Past Hosts
item.description: Laurence Tubiana, France’s top climate change envoy, is deploying the full extent of her and her country’s charms in hopes of facilitating an accord.
item.category: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change
item.dc:creator: CORAL DAVENPORT
item.media:credit: Pierre Terdjman for The New York Times
item.media:description: Laurence Tubiana has applied the full extent of her diplomatic skills to her role in facilitating the Paris climate talks.

item.title: France’s Far-Right National Front Gains in Regional Elections
item.description: The party, led by Marine Le Pen, has thrived on an anti-immigration message and is projected to win two of France’s 13 regions and is leading in several others.
item.dc:creator: ALISSA J. RUBIN
item.media:description: The leader of the National Front, Marine Le Pen, center, greeted supporters after voting Sunday in Henin-Beaumont, France.

item.title: Memo From Argentina: Her Time Is Up, but Argentina’s President Is Not Going Quietly
item.description: With late decrees and appointments, President Cristina Fernández de Kirchner appears to be making the transition of power as difficult as possible for her successor, Mauricio Macri.
item.dc:creator: JONATHAN GILBERT
item.media:description: Mauricio Macri upended Argentine politics by winning the presidential vote last month.

item.title: News Analysis: Trust and Money at Core of Crucial Paris Talks on Climate Change
item.description: Whether governments can be trusted to do what they say they will do is the question that will determine whether a Paris climate change accord has teeth.
item.category: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change
item.dc:creator: CORAL DAVENPORT
item.media:description: On Sunday, hundreds of people in Paris formed a message about how to confront climate change.

item.title: India Gets Cash Flowing as Banks Open Sunday After Flood
item.description: India’s banks will work on Sunday to aid residents left without food, power and access to money in the flood-hit southern city of Chennai and surrounding areas.
item.dc:creator: REUTERS
item.media:description: People waved to an Indian Coast Guard helicopter on Sunday in the southern city of Chennai, parts of which have been under eight feet of water in the worst flooding there in a century. About 280 people have died across Tamil Nadu, of which Chennai is the capital, since rains began last week.

item.title: Chinese Businessman Linked to Corruption Scandals Dies in Prison, Reports Say
item.description: Xu Ming, 44, once the eighth-richest person in China, died of a heart attack, according to news reports, less than a year before his expected release.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL FORSYTHE

item.title: Car Bomb Kills Governor in Aden, Yemeni Security Official Says
item.description: The governor, Jaafer Mohamed Saad, is the most senior official to be killed in the city where the embattled President Abdu Rabbu Mansour Hadi is based.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: SAEED AL-BATATI and KAREEM FAHIM
item.media:description: The scene of the attack on Sunday in Aden, Yemen. Security officials said that a car bomb blast had killed the provincial governor and at least four of his bodyguards.

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: Malaysia’s Balancing Act
item.description: Some Southeast Asian states are hedging between the U.S. and China. That’s good for regional stability, and for America, too.
item.dc:creator: CHENG-CHWEE KUIK

item.title: The Jeweler Wallace Chan: 'The Stone Is Me'
item.description: The Hong Kong-based jeweler’s efforts to draw the best from gems produces glittering results.
item.dc:creator: JOYCE LAU
item.media:credit: Billy H.C. Kwok for The New York Times
item.media:description: Wallace Chan, working on designs in his private showroom in Hong Kong.

item.title: ‘You Ain’t No Muslim, Bruv’: Response to London Attack Inspires Hashtag
item.description: The words of a bystander, shouted at the suspect in a knife attack in a London subway station, became a worldwide trending term on Twitter.
item.dc:creator: PATRICK LAFORGE

item.title: Tashfeen Malik, Suspect in California Attack, Remains Mystery to Relatives
item.description: Relatives in Pakistan struggled to reconcile the woman they described as having a promising future with the one accused of unleashing carnage in San Bernardino.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: LIAM STACK

item.title: Knife Attack in London Subway Called ‘Terrorist Incident’
item.description: The police arrested a 29-year-old man in the assault, in which one person was seriously wounded, but did not say why they considered it a terrorist attack.
item.dc:creator: STEPHEN CASTLE

item.title: Taliban Release Audio Purported to Be of Their Leader
item.description: The Taliban said the recording was from Mullah Akhtar Muhammad Mansour, who in recent days was rumored to be killed or wounded in a shooting in Pakistan.
item.dc:creator: ROD NORDLAND
item.media:description: Mullah Akhtar Muhammad Mansour, the supreme leader of the Taliban, in an undated photo.

item.title: World Briefing | Middle East: Lebanon: Bomb Kills 3 During Raid
item.description: A man suspected of being an Islamist militant killed himself and two members of his family in northern Lebanon on Saturday when he set of explosives during an army raid on his home.
item.dc:creator: REUTERS

item.title: World Briefing | Europe: Austria: A Nose for Police Work
item.description: The Vienna police say they have discovered a plantation with more than 700 marijuana plants at a warehouse close to a center for police dogs.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing | Asia: Bangladesh: Bomb Explodes at Temple
item.description: A bomb was set off outside a Hindu temple in northern Bangladesh early Saturday, wounding at least six people, the police said.
item.dc:creator: JULFIKAR ALI MANIK

item.title: World Briefing | Asia: Azerbaijan: 30 Missing After Rig Fire
item.description: One worker was killed, 30 were missing and 33 were rescued Saturday after a fire swept through a Caspian Sea oil platform owned by Azerbaijan’s state oil company Socar, the company said.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS
